content: The "Executive Accountability Act of 2002" allows for an exception to the $1,000,000 limitation on deductible compensation in certain cases. The "Executive Accountability Act of 2002" allows for an exception to the $1,000,000 limitation on deductible compensation in certain cases. Paragraph (4) of section 162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to exclude certain factors from being taken into account when determining if performance goals are met. The amendment made by this section applies to taxable years after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 409A denies deferral for funded deferred compensation of corporate insiders if the corporation funds a defined contribution plan with employer stock. If an employer maintains a defined contribution plan with employer stock and a funded deferred compensation plan, deferred compensation of corporate insiders must be included in gross income when there is no substantial risk of forfeiture. The tax treatment of amounts available under the plan is determined under section 72. The term "plan" refers to any compensation deferral plan where the employee's rights are no greater than a general creditor, all funds for deferred compensation are owned by the employer until paid out, and the funds are available to creditors at all times. The term "plan" refers to a compensation deferral plan that does not include a qualified employer plan. Special rules apply, such as deferred compensation being paid only upon separation from service, death, or at a specified time, and no acceleration of payment by any event. If there is a modification to accelerate payment, all previously deferred compensation is affected. If a modification accelerates payment in a compensation deferral plan, all previously deferred compensation becomes taxable in the year of the modification. The taxpayer must pay interest on the underpayments that would have occurred if the compensation had been included in gross income when deferred. Additionally, a plan must meet certain requirements regarding creditor's rights for amounts set aside in a trust. The term "corporate insider" refers to individuals subject to Securities Exchange Act requirements. Trust assets must be accessible to general creditors as if held directly by the employer in the US. The term "plan" includes any agreement or arrangement, and rights to compensation are subject to a substantial risk of forfeiture if conditioned on future performance of substantial services. SEC. 409A denies deferral for funded deferred compensation of corporate insiders if the corporation funds a defined contribution plan with employer stock. The effective date for these amendments applies to amounts deferred after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 4 includes in income certain deferred amounts of insiders of corporations that expatriate to avoid US income tax. SEC. 91 addresses unrealized gains on stock options of insiders of corporations that expatriate to avoid US income tax. SEC. 91 addresses the inclusion of net unrealized built-in gains on stock options held by corporate insiders of expatriate corporations as ordinary income. Definitions for "corporate insider" and "expatriate corporation" are provided. The term 'expatriate corporation' refers to the acquiring corporation in a corporate expatriation transaction where a nominally foreign corporation acquires substantially all properties. In a corporate expatriation transaction, if more than 80 percent of the acquiring corporation's stock is held by former shareholders of the domestic corporation, certain ownership requirements apply. This percentage can be lowered to 50 percent for a nominally foreign corporation. In a corporate expatriation transaction, a foreign corporation is considered as such if it lacks substantial business activities in the country of its creation, and its publicly traded stock primarily trades in the United States. This definition also encompasses partnership transactions. A corporate expatriation transaction involves a foreign corporation acquiring properties of a domestic partnership, where more than 80 percent of the acquiring corporation's stock is held by former partners of the partnership. The acquiring corporation in a corporate expatriation transaction must meet specific requirements, including having more than 80 percent of its stock held by former partners of the domestic partnership or related foreign partnerships. Special rules apply, treating a series of related transactions as one transaction. In a corporate expatriation transaction, the acquiring corporation must meet certain requirements, such as having over 80% of its stock held by former partners of the domestic partnership or related foreign partnerships. Special rules apply to treat a series of related transactions as one transaction. The term 'nominally foreign corporation' refers to a corporation that would be considered foreign if not for certain conditions. The term 'net realized built-in gain' pertains to the amount that would be included in gross income if options to acquire stock in a corporation were exercised. The 'expanded affiliated group' is defined as a group that includes the acquiring corporation and excludes stock held by members of the group. The term 'expanded affiliated group' refers to an affiliated group without certain restrictions. SEC. 91 addresses deferred amounts of insiders of corporations expatriating to avoid US income tax. The effective date for these amendments is after September 11, 2001. SEC. 5 discusses the application of golden parachute excise tax to deferred compensation paid by corporations after a major decline in stock value or bankruptcy declaration. The amendment to Section 4999 of the Internal Revenue Code introduces a tax on deferred compensation paid to corporate insiders after a significant stock value decline or bankruptcy. This tax applies to excess parachute payments, including severance pay, received under specific conditions. The amendment to Section 4999 of the Internal Revenue Code imposes a tax on deferred compensation paid to corporate insiders in cases where the corporation becomes a debtor in a title 11 case within a specified period. The term "corporate insider" refers to individuals subject to certain Securities Exchange Act requirements. This amendment applies to employment cessations after the enactment of the Act.
